Laboratory Results: Her electrocardiogram and initial cardiac enzymes are normal.
Main Information: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with an episode of chest pain, shortness of breath, profuse sweating, and rapid heart rate. She has no significant past medical history or current medications and reports she felt as if she was going to die. The symptoms subsided before her arrival at the emergency department. She never experienced similar symptoms before.

Physical Examination Findings: Scleral icterus, significant hepatosplenomegaly, and mild peripheral edema were observed during physical examination.
Laboratory Results: Elevated serum levels of bilirubin, aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase (ALP), γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGTP), immunoglobulins, and cholesterol (especially HDL fraction) were found. The patient tested negative for antiviral antibodies. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was also elevated, and Anti-mitochondrial antibodies were present. Histopathologic examination from a liver biopsy showed bile duct injury, cholestasis, and granuloma formation.
Main Information: A 55-year-old woman presented with severe pruritus and fatigue. She has no significant past medical history or similar symptoms in the past.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 5. Physical exam is notable for subcutaneous emphysema in the clavicular area.
Laboratory Results: Chest radiography demonstrates proper tube location and resolution of the pneumothorax. On the trauma intensive care unit, a repeat chest radiograph is notable for a recurrent pneumothorax with the chest tube in place.
Main Information: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. He is subsequently intubated. Needle decompression and chest tube placement are performed, and the patient is stabilized after receiving 2 units of blood and 2 liters of fluid. The patient is transferred to the trauma intensive care unit.

Physical Examination Findings: Patient presenting with shortness of breath, substernal chest pain increased by inspiration, distended neck veins, and symptoms of fever and malaise. Physical examination shows bilateral basilar rales and muffled heart sounds. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), pulse of 125/min, respirations of 32/min, and blood pressure of 85/45 mm Hg.
Laboratory Results: ECG shows sinus tachycardia, diffuse ST segment elevation, low voltage QRS complexes, and fluctuating R wave amplitude.
Main Information: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 12 hours after the sudden onset of symptoms. He has also had a nonproductive cough for the past 5 days. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient has symptoms of increasing breast tenderness, nausea, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain, and urinary frequency. She shows mild, nontender abdominal enlargement. The cervical os is closed. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg.
Laboratory Results: Urine β-hCG is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities.
Main Information: A 34-year-old woman is requesting prenatal care. The date of her last menstrual period is unknown. She has been trying to conceive with her husband since she stopped taking oral contraceptives 6 months ago and believes she is pregnant.

Physical Examination Findings: Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. A 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on her right thigh. When the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards.
Main Information: A 38-year-old woman has a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks.

Physical Examination Findings: Clinical examination shows a diastolic murmur, which is prominent when she lies on her left side. Jugular venous distention is present, and chest examination reveals fine crackles that do not clear with coughing.
Laboratory Results: Chest X-ray shows pulmonary congestion, and 2-dimensional echocardiogram shows a mass in the left atrium attached to the atrial septum.
Main Information: A 41-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath that is worse when she lies on her left side. About 10 days ago, she had an episode of unexplained loss of consciousness. Past medical history is negative and family history is irrelevant.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient presents with painless swelling of the neck for the past week. On physical examination, multiple non-tender lymph nodes, averaging 2 cm in diameter, are found to be palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. No other lymphadenopathy is noted. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory Results: Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14 g/dL, Leukocyte count 8000/mm3 with a normal differential, Platelet count 250,000/mm3, Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 40 mm/h.
Main Information: A 25-year-old man has a past medical history significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, diagnosed last year. He also experienced a head trauma 5 years ago, which has been complicated by residual seizures. His only medication is daily phenytoin, which was restarted after he had a seizure 3 months ago. He reports no recent fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. His temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉). An excisional biopsy of one of the cervical lymph nodes is performed and the histopathologic analysis is pending.

Physical Examination Findings: The 18-year-old girl looks relatively short, is otherwise healthy and vitals are within normal limits. She exhibits the presence of axillary hair, breast development, and pubic hair at Tanner stage 5. She has been experiencing mild intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past year.
Laboratory Results: Her labs are significant for the following: FSH level is 7 mIU/mL (Normal follicular phase range: 3.1 – 7.9 mIU/mL; Ovulation peak range: 2.3 – 18.5 mIU/mL; Luteal phase range: 1.4 – 5.5 mIU/mL; Postmenopausal range: 30.6 – 106.3 mIU/mL). Estradiol level is 28 pg/mL (Normal mid-follicular phase range: 27 – 123 pg/mL; Periovulatory range: 96 – 436 pg/mL; Mid-luteal phase range: 49 – 294 pg/mL; Postmenopausal range: 0 – 40 pg/mL). Testosterone level is 52 ng/dL (Normal range: 40 – 60 ng/dL).
Main Information: An 18-year-old girl has not yet menstruated. She and her mother recently immigrated from another country, they do not have any previous medical records. A complete vaginal examination was declined by both mother and daughter, who preferred that a lab test be performed.

Physical Examination Findings: Patient's temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Physical exam reveals a tense abdomen with a board like rigidity and positive rebound tenderness.
Laboratory Results: An erect abdominal x-ray is ordered.
Main Information: A 55-year-old man experienced severe abdominal pain for the past 1 hour. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease and has been treated with antacids without a good response. He vomited repeatedly in the last couple of hours, his vomitus being brown/red in color.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient is afebrile and his vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an irritable middle age man who is tense and somewhat inattentive during the interview.
Laboratory Results: No laboratory findings are mentioned in the text.
Main Information: A 35-year-old man presents with a 7 month history of insomnia. The patient admitted to having trouble sleeping from a young age but became more aware of how much this is affecting his health after attending a sleep conference earlier this year. He is worried that his health has suffered because of this, and he is also concerned that he will not be able to pay his bills if he were to get sick. He has no past medical or psychiatric condition and is not known to use any recreational drugs. The patient arrived for his appointment an hour early because he was afraid he might miss it.

Physical Examination Findings: Multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable.
Laboratory Results: A complete blood count is normal. Prothrombin time (PT) 12 sec. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 60 sec.
Main Information: A 9-year-old boy is brought in by his mother because of bruising on his torso and limbs. The patient’s mother denies any other symptoms and says he is otherwise healthy.

Physical Examination Findings: Patient has a fever with temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F); he presents with a pruritic rash that started on his trunk and then spread to his face and extremities.
Laboratory Results: No laboratory results provided.
Main Information: The patient is an 18-month-old boy experiencing a 2-day history of fever and a pruritic rash. The boy has not received any childhood vaccinations as his parents believe they are dangerous.

Physical Examination Findings: On physical examination, there is an erythematous, well-demarcated patch on his left thigh, over his pubic region, and throughout the perineum. The scrotum is spared.
Main Information: A 19-year-old man with a past medical history significant only for facial acne presents with increased inguinal pruritis. Relevant social history includes participation in school wrestling. He has no significant family history. Other than the pruritic rash, a review of systems is negative.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient's vital signs are heart rate 72/min, respiratory rate 14/min, temperature 37.9°C (100.2°F), and blood pressure 100/74 mm Hg. Physical examination indicates mild diffuse abdominal tenderness, and yellowing of the skin
Laboratory Results: Blood tests show an alanine aminotransferase level (ALT) of 2,000 IU/L. Hepatitis viral panel shows Anti-HAV IgM negative, HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, IgM anti-HBc positive, Anti-HCV negative, Anti-HDV negative
Main Information: A 25-year-old man is experiencing extreme fatigue for the past 2 days and is concerned about his yellow skin. He has no other complaints and is denying any fever or headache. Patient has a history of illicit intravenous drugs use and does not have any immunization records due to relocation from Africa to the US at age 18.

Physical Examination Findings: Patient appears constantly tired, speaking more slowly than usual and has decreased appetite.
Laboratory Results: No laboratory results mentioned.
Main Information: 34-year-old man has a 2-month history of difficulty concentrating at work. He is afraid of losing his job due to poor performance. He wakes up early most mornings and finds it difficult to fall back asleep. He used to enjoy dance classes but has lost interest recently. He returned from a deployment to Afghanistan 2 years ago.

Physical Examination Findings: Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae. There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases.
Main Information: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has excessively dry skin. His mother says that he has had dry, scaly skin since he was 6 months old. She says it is worse in winter and better in summer. There is no associated itching, redness, or discharge.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient presented with shortness of breath and right-sided chest pain that worsened with inspiration. Her physical examination shows decreased air movement throughout the right lung but otherwise clear lungs on auscultation, grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur, and a gravid uterus without acute findings. Other vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 126/74 mm Hg, heart rate 87/min, and respiratory rate 23/min. She is afebrile, tachycardic to 121/min, normotensive, and demonstrates an O2 saturation of 92%.
Laboratory Results: No laboratory or diagnostic test findings mentioned
Main Information: The patient is a 31-year-old G1-P0 woman at 28-weeks gestation, who reports to have recently returned from a trip to New York. She works as a graduate student at the local university. Her medical history is positive only for frequent bouts of sinusitis. She denies any smoking and past illicit drug use, but admits to drinking a glass of red wine daily.

Physical Examination Findings: Several areas of point tenderness are found on the occipital region, elbows, and medial surface of both knees.
Laboratory Results: Laboratory work up is unremarkable.
Main Information: A 38-year-old woman is being evaluated by her primary care physician for chronic, widespread pain that started around 5 months ago. This pain has been accompanied by sleeping issues. Her friend recommended that she try yoga to relieve the pain, but she says this has not helped her at all. She says the symptoms have begun to impact her daily functions and keep her from doing things she used to enjoy. Past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder, for which she currently takes no medication. The patient had been previously medicated with paroxetine for 5 years.

Physical Examination Findings: His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses.
Main Information: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin.

Physical Examination Findings: Clinical examination shows mild tenderness in the suprapubic region, and there is no organomegaly.
Laboratory Results: Findings on colonoscopy include patchy erythema and ulceration in the cecum, ascending, descending, and sigmoid colon. Mucosal biopsy shows colonic crypts with lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates.
Main Information: A 30-year-old woman presents to the physician because of ongoing diarrhea for the past 1 month. She reports that diarrhea has been intermittently present for the past month. The stool is often loose and associated with blood and lower abdominal pain. She denies any recent travel history, and she works at a nursing home as a caretaker. She is not currently on any medications.

Physical Examination Findings: Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation
Laboratory Results: An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.5-cm nodule with irregular borders at the apex of the left lung with no mediastinal or hilar enlargement
Main Information: A 45-year-old African-American woman experienced an episode of hemoptysis. Over the past 8 months, she has had a nonproductive cough, fatigue, and lost 9-kg (20-lb) weight. She drinks a glass of wine every night and does not smoke. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She does not take any medications and she has never traveled out of the country. She works as an accountant.

Physical Examination Findings: Pallor and general weakness
Laboratory Results: Laboratory studies reveal anemia as well as an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) reveals a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM; serum IgM concentration is 6.3 g/dL.
Main Information: A 68-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and weight loss. He is especially concerned about a recent episode in which he noticed a blurring of his vision and headache; he also notes that his “memory is not as good as it used to be,” which his wife confirms.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient has a temperature of 98.7°F (37.1°C), a blood pressure of 149/92 mmHg, a pulse rate of 83/min, respirations are 15/min, and an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. No remarkable findings on the physical exam.
Laboratory Results: An initial head CT scan shows normal results.
Main Information: The 22-year-old female patient has reported to the emergency department for a severe headache that is not responding to ibuprofen, is worse when laying down, and is associated with transient vision loss, blurry vision, and ringing in the ears. She has a past medical history of headaches, obesity, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and constipation.

Physical Examination Findings: Abdominal and rectal exams are normal.
Laboratory Results: Routine screening found positive fecal occult blood tests. A colonoscopy revealed a polyp in the descending colon with no other abnormalities. Excisional biopsy of the polyp shows 75% tubular architecture.
Main Information: A 62-year-old man is asymptomatic but with a family history of large intestinal cancer (his father died of large intestinal cancer).

Physical Examination Findings: Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. Physical examination is within normal limits except for signs of dehydration.
Main Information: A 20-year-old male college student presents to the emergency room at 4 AM in the morning with complaints of abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 hours. He was studying for his exams last night when he became hungry and ate some food from the afternoon after heating it for a while. He says that his symptoms began an hour after he ate the food.

Physical Examination Findings: Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. A focused chest exam reveals mild crepitus on the right side.
Laboratory Results: A chest X-ray shows a cavitary lesion in the right lung which is confirmed on chest computed tomography (CT). A lung biopsy reveals necrotic granulomatous inflammation with oval yeast in macrophages.
Main Information: A 79-year-old woman presents with a persistent non-productive cough and dyspnea after contracting a cold in the past month. She describes herself as being “generally healthy” before the cold started. Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. Her parents are both deceased. She does not smoke and only drinks alcohol occasionally. During a review of symptoms, she described a month-long trip to St. Louis, Missouri, to visit family.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry.
Main Information: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol.

Physical Examination Findings: His temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 105/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, a mild conjunctival pallor is evident, and the rectum is erythematous, indurated, and tender.
Laboratory Results: Colonoscopy demonstrates continuous mucosal lesions throughout the rectum to the hepatic flexure of the colon.
Main Information: A 41-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaints of abdominal discomfort and cramping for the past 4 months. He also mentions that he has grossly bloody stool and most of the time an urge to defecate. He has a history of bulimia with laxative abuse several years ago. He admits having lost about 5 lb in the past month.

Physical Examination Findings: The physical examination is unremarkable, except for a mildly tender prostate, without masses or nodules. There are no testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids.
Laboratory Results: A urine test showed negative for white cells and culture in a mid-stream urine sample. However, expressed prostatic secretion test was positive for white cells but negative for culture.
Main Information: A 45-year-old man presents to your office with a 2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria), and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. He has been evaluated by several practitioners, who have all prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, with no improvement and leading to emotional distress and sleep disturbances. Additionally to this health issue, you have also been following him for recurrent abdominal pain, periods of constipation and diarrhea, and fatigability, with all test results within the normal range thus far.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
Main Information: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a change in his personality. The mother reports that over the past 7 months her son has become increasingly withdrawn; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. He had always been a quiet boy, who needed some time on his own, but he used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and “stealing his thoughts”. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke marijuana occasionally but quit 1 year ago. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's sequence of thoughts. He is anxious and has a flat affect.

Physical Examination Findings: The 5-year-old boy is somnolent and diaphoretic.
Laboratory Results: Serum studies showed a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. After dextrose infusion, his glucose concentration normalizes. However, he has another episode of decreased consciousness where serum studies show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1).
Main Information: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to a sudden loss of consciousness. His medical history includes asthma with multiple hospitalizations. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. After the dextrose infusion, his symptoms improve and he is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, the boy experiences another episode of decreased consciousness.

Physical Examination Findings: On physical exam, the patient’s fingernails appear flat and mild conjunctival pallor is noted.
Laboratory Results: An upper barium esophagram shows an upper esophageal web. A complete blood count reveals: Hb% 10 gm/dL, Total count (WBC) 11,000 /mm3, Differential count: Neutrophile 70%, Lymphocytes 25%, Monocytes 5%, ESR 10 mm/hr
Main Information: A 61-year-old woman presents to an outpatient clinic with fatigue and mild neck pain for a month. She adds that she is having difficulty swallowing. She denies trouble with her breathing but endorses 5–10 lb of unintentional weight loss over the past few months.

Physical Examination Findings: The boy appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
Main Information: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight.

Physical Examination Findings: The boy has light-colored skin with silver-colored hair.
Laboratory Results: Neutrophils contain large cytoplasmic vacuoles. Genetic studies show a mutation in the LYST gene.
Main Information: A 6-month-old boy presents to a pediatrician for the evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections. He has a history of a variety of bacterial infections since birth. The pediatrician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder and decides to order several tests.

Physical Examination Findings: On physical exam the patient has decreased passive and active range of motion of his shoulder. Strength of the patient's upper extremity is 4/5.
Laboratory Results: None
Main Information: A 65-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for stiffness in his arm. He states that he has been having trouble combing his hair and reaching objects that are high on the shelf. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, obesity, and hypertension. His current medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient admits to leading a sedentary life in which he tends to stay home and watch television. He does not engage in any physical or strenuous activity.

Physical Examination Findings: several brown greasy appearing lesions on his forehead
Main Information: A 77-year-old man comes to the office for a routine visit. He is doing well. His only complaint is the recent appearance of lesions on his forehead that he can't seem to peel off.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient's temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉), and the blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The physical examination shows no abnormalities other than a reduced range of motion and crepitus in both knees.
Laboratory Results: Hemoglobin 15 g/dL, Leukocyte count 58,000/mm3, Platelet count 250,000/mm3, Flow cytometry on the peripheral blood reveals an absolute lymphocyte count of 50,000/mm3.
Main Information: A 75-year-old man presents himself for an annual blood pressure check-up and blood work. He has no complaints other than occasional knee pain. His past medical history includes hypertension. He has had knee osteoarthritis for several years and takes acetaminophen occasionally for pain control. His diet is mainly comprised of vegetables and he exercises daily. He has no history of smoking. His brother died at age 84 due to hematologic malignancy.

Physical Examination Findings: Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal.
Laboratory Results: Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells.
Main Information: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days.

Physical Examination Findings: Patient reports dizziness and palpitations for 2 days.
Laboratory Results: An ECG was performed.
Main Information: A previously healthy 28-year-old man attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games prior to the onset of the symptoms.

Physical Examination Findings: Physical examination reveals a small child in distress. She is laying on the examination table with her knees drawn to her chest. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh, systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper left sternal border.
Main Information: A 2-year-old girl is brought in to the office by her parents. They state that their daughter has recently been more irritable than usual, and she occasionally becomes pale and blue. Her parents note that she was diagnosed with a heart murmur, but it was never treated.

Physical Examination Findings: A painless mass in the left testicle of a 10-year-old boy
Laboratory Results: AFP 350 ng/mL (normal value < 10 ng/mL), hCG 0.4 IU/L (normal value < 0.5 IU/L), Biopsy: Presence of glomeruli-like structures with a central capillary within a mesodermal core, lined by flattened layers of germ cells.
Main Information: The patient was brought to his pediatrician after discovering the mass.

Physical Examination Findings: Blood pressure is 120/88 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), and respiratory rate is 16/min.
Laboratory Results: Potassium level of 3.3 mmol/L and serum calcium of 11 mg/dL.
Main Information: A 28-year-old woman presents with facial flushing, weakness, and chronic diarrhea for the past month. She denies any history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. The patient was on a trip to Thailand 2 years ago with her family but denies any recent travel. Laboratory findings are unremarkable. The attending physician suspects that this might be a case of a genetic mutation in the menin 1 gene on chromosome 11 and orders a genetic analysis.

Physical Examination Findings: Her physical exam is within normal limits. She brought a picture of her swollen hand.
Laboratory Results: C1-inhibitor levels are ordered and found to be extremely low.
Main Information: A 22-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of swelling in her face, hands, and neck with occasional abdominal pain. The symptoms usually resolve in 2 to 3 days. She has had these swelling events her whole life; however, they have become more debilitating recently. Last week she had an event that restricted her ability to eat and swallow.  Past medical history is noncontributory. Her father is alive and well with no significant medical history. Her mother and her maternal aunt have a similar condition. The treating physician has a strong suspicion of an inherited disorder.

Physical Examination Findings: Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the right outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy.
Laboratory Results: Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia.
Main Information: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient has dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His achilles reflex is 1+.
Main Information: A 53-year-old man has been experiencing a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. It is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also lost 4.6-kg (10.1-lb) weight over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years.

Physical Examination Findings: Tense axillary bullae are noted in the patient's axilla that do not rupture with light, gloved touch.
Laboratory Results: On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane.
Main Information: An 81-year-old man recently moved into an assisted living facility. He presents with itchy blisters in his axilla which he attributes to a poor diet. He has also been started on 4 new medications by the nurse practitioner at the facility, in addition to his existing prescriptions.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits.
Main Information: A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble sleeping. The patient states that he recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery. When the patient retired, his goal was to finally be able to go out with his wife; however, he finds that he is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. His inability to stay awake has been straining his marriage as his wife is disappointed that they cannot do any activities in the evening together. The patient has tried drinking caffeine but finds that it does not help. The patient’s wife claims that the patient seems to sleep peacefully, and the patient states he feels rested when he awakes. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome which is managed with fiber supplements.

Physical Examination Findings: Patient presents with a several day history of edema.
Laboratory Results: Serum Na+: 140 mmol/L, Serum K+: 3.5 mmol/L, Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL, Total serum bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL, Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL, Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and fatty casts, Hodgkin's corpuscular volume 94 μm3, Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3, Platelet count 45,000/mm3
Main Information: A 25-year-old female with Hodgkin's disease

Physical Examination Findings: A 55-year-old woman presents with a heart rate of 86/min, respiratory rate of 15/min, temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F), and blood pressure of 111/79 mm Hg.
Laboratory Results: Her laboratory results are significant for Calcium of 13.8 mg/dL and PTH of 230 pg/mL. Her complete metabolic panel is otherwise within normal limits. Imaging studies show subperiosteal resorption and osteoporosis. Scintigraphy reveals the most common pathologic condition associated with the patient’s diagnosis.
Main Information: The patient has been feeling weak for the past 2 years and has been urinating a considerable volume every time she goes to the bathroom. She has no past medical history.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient's temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is quiet with a flattened affect, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly.
Laboratory Results: No laboratory results were provided in this case.
Main Information: A 35-year-old woman has been experiencing several periods of depressed mood for the past 3 years. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and usually resolve after 4-6 weeks. During these episodes, she has sleep disturbances, depressed mood, and poor appetite. She also reports experiencing occasional episodes of elevated mood over the past ten years resulting in increased productivity at work and reduced sleep. Her past medical history includes obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis. She is on insulin and methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally.

Physical Examination Findings: Physical examination is significant for localized tenderness to palpation over the left anteromedial proximal tibia, 6 cm inferior to the joint line. There is no joint effusion noted. Valgus stress testing is negative for any pain or instability of the knee joint.
Laboratory Results: Radiographs of the left knee are obtained and reveal only mild arthritis, without evidence of any fractures or bony lesions.
Main Information: An obese 42-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of left knee pain for the past 3 months. She describes the pain as affecting the inside part of the knee as well as the front of her knee, below the kneecap. She denies any inciting injury or trauma to the knee but reports that the pain is worse when she is climbing up stairs or rising from a chair.

Physical Examination Findings: Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm rubbery, mobile mass that is nontender in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast.
Laboratory Results: A biopsy of the mass shows rounded contour with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue.
Main Information: A 33-year-old woman at 17-weeks gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless mass in the right breast for the last 3 weeks that has not increased in size.

Physical Examination Findings: Significant swelling and redness of the patient's fingers causing her significant pain. The distal interphalangeal joints are swollen, warm, and painful. Pitted and cracked nails. Stiff and slightly swollen right knee. Rough, erythematous skin patches seen over her elbows.
Main Information: The 31-year-old female patient presented with swelling, redness and pain in her fingers and stiffness and slight swelling in her right knee. She also showed signs of fatigue and difficulty moving. She revealed that her father has a similar condition. They both use hydrating creams and topical glucocorticoids with moderate benefit.

Physical Examination Findings: Temperature is 106°F (41.1°C), blood pressure is 109/62 mmHg, pulse is 170/min, respirations are 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Patient has an altered mental status, minimal muscle tone, and is incoherent when answering questions. The patient is also covered in sweat and dirt. His Glasgow Coma Scale is rated 10.
Main Information: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was found down at his construction workplace. The patient underwent anesthesia for an appendectomy several months ago. He has a medical history of schizophrenia which is well controlled with haloperidol. He is currently taking phenytoin for epilepsy and propranolol for anxiety and hyperthyroidism.

Physical Examination Findings: The small, round, and painless swelling, which was detected 3 weeks ago in the middle of her neck, has now increased in size. The swelling is associated with sweaty palms and soles, insomnia, irritability, nervousness, and fatigue. Local examination reveals a 3 x 3 cm round, non-tender, non-fluctuant, and non-pulsatile swelling in the anterior triangle of her neck. The vital signs are within normal limits.
Laboratory Results: The patient carries a total white blood cell count of 10,200/mm3, including 70% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, and zero eosinophils.The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/hr (normal, 0–29 mm/hr).
Main Information: A 40-year-old woman presents to her family physician with a 3-week history of swollen neck. However, the patient does not complain of fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, weight loss, vision problems, or body swelling. The patient’s medical history is negative for similar symptoms or a thyroid disorder.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient's temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is breathing on his own and has strong distal pulses. The patient's strength in his upper extremities is 1/5. He has reduced sensation in his upper extremities. The patient's lower extremities reveal 5/5 strength with intact sensation.
Laboratory Results: No significant findings as the chest radiograph and basic labs have yet to be reported.
Main Information: A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient was an unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. He has a past medical history of asthma, depression, and anxiety. He is not currently taking any medications. The patient is discharged with follow up instructions after no significant fractures or injuries are found. The patient then presents 4 months later to his primary doctor with weakness.

Physical Examination Findings: Physical examination is significant for tenderness and warmth over the anterior aspect of the left thigh.
Laboratory Results: A plain radiograph of the left femur shows increased cortical thickness with widened intercortical space. Laboratory studies show: Alkaline phosphatase 925 U/L, Serum calcium 9.2 mg/dL, Serum phosphorus 4.4 mg/dL.
Main Information: A 65-year-old man presents with pain in his left thigh for a week. He describes the pain as dull and constant, boring in nature, and localized deep below the thigh muscle. He says it is worse at night. Findings on bone biopsy are shown in the image.

Physical Examination Findings: Not provided
Laboratory Results: Not provided
Main Information: A 28-year-old male reports disturbing flashbacks, upsetting dreams, and anxiety intensified by loud noises or associations to past traumatic experiences from his active duty in Iraq. These symptoms emerged about 7 weeks after his return, leading him to take a leave from his military duties, avoid familiar situations triggering his anxiety, and stay isolated at home.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient has unconsciousness. His respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg, and pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg.
Laboratory Results: Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is negative. An electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves.
Main Information: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies.

Physical Examination Findings: The boy is at the 5th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally.
Laboratory Results: Na+ 145 mEq/L, K+ 4.1 mEq/L, Cl- 102 mEq/L, HCO3- 25 mEq/L, Ca2+ 9.4 mg/dL, Glucose 110 mg/dL, Thyroid-stimulating hormone 0.3 μU/mL, Thyroxine 3.9 μg/dL, Insulin-like growth factor 1 24 ng/mL (N=61–356 ng/mL), Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 2.1 mcg/mL (N=1.6–6.5 μg/mL)
Main Information: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size have changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in).

Physical Examination Findings: The patient is slightly built, appears thin, anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. The patient's weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is observed. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack.
Laboratory Results: The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also present.
Main Information: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She has a history of hypertension and is on antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has experienced a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. Patient complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months.

Physical Examination Findings: The vital signs include blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness.
Laboratory Results: Serum sodium 136 mEq/L, Serum potassium 4.2 mEq/L, Calcium 13.2 mg/dL, Bicarbonate 26 mEq/L. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple duodenal ulcers.
Main Information: A 26-year-old man presents to the office complaining of persistent epigastric pain for the past 2 months. He states that his pain is worse a few hours after he eats. His father had similar symptoms. Past medical history is insignificant. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol.

Physical Examination Findings: The vital signs of the newborn include body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate 130/min, and respiratory rate 45/min. Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity, while the skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign.
Laboratory Results: Not provided
Main Information: A 7 -day-old newborn boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. During the first 2 days of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using acetaminophen; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet.

Physical Examination Findings: The physical examination reveals dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area with atrophy of the labia minora. The clitoris appears retracted. The perianal skin appears pale and wrinkled.
Main Information: A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe vulvar itching that has been gradually worsening for the past year. She mentions that she has tried over-the-counter lubricants, but lubricants do not seem to provide substantial relief. Her medical history is remarkable for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. She has been sexually active with her husband until recently and reports severe pain during vaginal intercourse.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.4°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg. Her cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings.
Laboratory Results: An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block.
Main Information: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and was being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and her arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness. She works as an event manager and has had more stress than usual due to a recent concert tour. She appears well.

Physical Examination Findings: The patient is oriented to person and time but not place or situation. She does not seem to recognize her doctor despite knowing him for many years. She becomes somnolent intermittently throughout the interview. She can recall 0/3 words after 5 minutes. She has a low-frequency tremor in her right arm that increases in severity with deliberate movement. Her BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 99.8°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 115/65 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 17/min.
Laboratory Results: No laboratory or diagnostic test findings are mentioned.
Main Information: A 74-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to her primary care doctor by her son who is concerned about the patient's ability to manage her activities of daily living. She has been living alone since her husband passed away 2 years ago. She has remained an active member of her retirement community's wine club; however, she stopped attending the meetings 3 weeks ago. Her house appears more disorganized over the past 2 weeks. She generally drives short distances but avoids driving long distances as she occasionally gets lost when navigating new areas. She feels like her balance is getting worse, but she has not fallen. She has noticed increased urinary urgency over the past 8 months and has had 2 episodes of incontinence. Despite these changes, she reports feeling well. She drinks 4-6 glasses of wine per day. She was started on multiple medications for worsening anxiety by her psychiatrist 1 month ago.

Physical Examination Findings: Mental status examination shows laborious speech, The patient avoids eye contact
Main Information: A 19-year-old man is demonstrating strange behaviors such as dressing all in black and wearing long black coat even in the summer. He has always had difficulties fitting in, does not have friends, spends most of his time in his room playing online games, and is uncomfortable around other people. His academic performance is poor, mostly due to his interest in paranormal phenomena instead of doing his coursework. He experiences signs that he believes to be indications of demons' presence.

Physical Examination Findings: The physical exam shows increased resonance to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and crackles at the lung base. The patient's vitals include: heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 27/min, and blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg.
Laboratory Results: Chest radiography shows signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. Spirometry shows a forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%, a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%.
Main Information: A 79-year-old man presents to the office due to shortness of breath with moderate exertion and a slightly productive cough. He has a medical history of 25 years of heavy smoking.
